item.description:

26-Sep Map Design

Week 10 29-Oct Network Analysis Network Analysis Week 8-9 review
31-Oct Guest Lecture

14-Nov Make up day

Week number Date Milestones Class Lab Due
Week 1 27-Aug Welcomes Walk through
29-Aug Last day for a full refund 8⁄20 ESRI UC
Week 2 3-Sep Coordinate systems, projections Introduction to ArcMap Week 1 review
5-Sep Data Models and structures
Week 3 10-Sep GIS Data Datum Shift lab Week 2 review
12-Sep Last day to drop without a w 9⁄16 GPS
Week 4 17-Sep Getting Data GPS lab Week 3 review
19-Sep Last day to add or swap class 9⁄23 Map Design
Week 5 24-Sep Map Design Building A database Week 4 review
26-Sep Map Design
Week 6 1-Oct Vector Data Analysis Overlay lab Week 5 review
3-Oct Overlay analysis
Week 7 8-Oct Midterm Review No Lab Week 6 review
10-Oct Midterm Project proposal due
Week 8 15-Oct Fall Break! No Class Spatial Statistics Lab
17-Oct Spatial Statistics
Week 9 22-Oct Spatial Statistics Interpolation Lab
24-Oct Raster Data Analysis
Week 10 29-Oct Network Analysis Network Analysis Week 8-9 review
31-Oct Guest Lecture
Week 11 5-Nov Terrain Analysis Hydrology Lab week 10 review
7-Nov Terrain Analysis
Week 13 12-Nov Guest Lecture Distribution modeling weel 11 review
14-Nov Make up day
Week 14 19-Nov Las day to withdraw Make up day Open Lab
21-Nov Project Help
Week 15 26-Nov Project Help Open Lab Introduction due
28-Nov ThxGiving Break! No Class
Week 16 3-Dec Final Project presentations No Lab
5-Dec Final Project presentations
Week 17 10-Dec AGU - no class Practical Final on your own No Lab
12-Dec AGU - no class Practical Final on your own
Week 18 17-Dec Final Final at 1:30 Final Paper Due

Objective: Identify a biophysical, human, or environmental problem that requires or would benifit from your newfound knowledge of spatial analysis using GIS. Describe the problem that you are interested in. Provide geographic context to the problem. Discuss what kind of GIS analysis you want to use and the implementation strategy you have chosen. Present simple diagrams or maps that illustrate your approach. Apply your approach to real-world data and present the results of your project in oral form. All students are also required to write a term paper based on the final project. The intermediate deliverables count towards 10% of the final project grade, the term paper counts 65% of the final project grade and the presentation counts towards the remaining 25%.

All students are required to write a proposal for the final project. In the proposal, you will describe the project you are planning to carry out, the GIS datasets needed, and GIS analysis functions may be used in the project. You will review the literature, what methods and GIS analysis functions have been used solving similar problems. Each student should plan on a 15-minutes presentation of your final project to the class.

The term paper should include the following sections: - Introduction

  - Define the problem in context. Describe why spatial analysis is
    needed to solve your problem. Review in literature what methods
    and spatial analysis have been used solving similar problems. Be
    sure to include a statement like "The objective of this project
    is to ...".

  • Methods

    • Describe the strategy you solve the problem using GIS and any other necessary methods. Describe the statistic method, computer model, GIS analytic functions / operations you use in the problem solving process. Diagrams are especial helpful to understand your strategy.

  • Study Area and Analysis

    • Describe the study area. What kind of GIS data and data models are used in the analysis. Present the results of your analysis.

  • Results & Conclusions

    • Discuss the findings from your problem solving process. Evaluate your methodology. Discuss the usefulness and limitation of the analytic functions in GIS.

  • References

The following are due throughout the semester:

Proposal (1 ~ 3 pages, due tentatively on Oct 10th)

Introduction (due Nov. 26th)

Full Term Paper (6 ~ 15 pages, due on Dec 17th)
